Line 57: Line 57:
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of [[reproduction]]. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, given that the sexual activity of a male mantis is controlled by a brain-like [[ganglion]] in his abdomen it may not be appropriate to refer to him as a "corpse", even when he is decapitated.{{fact|date=June 2009}}
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of [[reproduction]]. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, given that the sexual activity of a male mantis is controlled by a brain-like [[ganglion]] in his abdomen it may not be appropriate to refer to him as a "corpse", even when he is decapitated.{{fact|date=June 2009}}
